qffFQTg3wOus5vNedIFf3A.text: wagamama has lots of potential. I saw other customers with dishes that looked amazingly tasty. Mine, though, was underwhelming. I made a stir fry myself the next night that was tastier, and healthier too. My friends, though, all seemed to enjoy their food, not least the white chocolate cheesecake they all shared. I didn't participate in the cake because I love only one chocolate--milk chocolate. Wagamama has a fun atmosphere, and it seems like a good place for large groups, what with the long tables and bag racks underneath. The service was friendly and efficient as well. Maybe I'll just order something else the next time.

htBw7MIaC_tPWXjZMoPepg.text: Same menu as all wagamamas, which is a good thing. Good food at a reasonable price. Nice building too!

5vQcvhCfXb5J2MBXnj9zdg.text: I know now why I haven't really enjoyed Wagamama in the past - I just wasn't ordering the right thing! This time around I got the vegetarian yasai  katsu curry and it was SO GOOD. I'm not a vegetarian and normally avoid vegetarian dishes (I love meat) but this was divine. "Sweet potato, aubergine and butternut squash deep-fried in panko breadcrumbs, served with a curry sauce and sticky white rice. garnished with dressed mixed leaves and red pickles". Yes please!

hEt340Zy1x0lbqy2aANCzg.text: Food nice enough but nothing special. Service efficient but can be busy. Think there's better value to be had from the non chain oriental food restaurants.

u1K4wgji7KWZGrfAbN5J7w.text: Wagamamas in Southwark is the same as most other branches, that's the problem with chain restaurants. The menu has something to suit all tastes and even my friend who doesn't like foreign food managed to find something that not only appealed, but she enjoyed.

xnT_RkN9IQyoZggz9D42lA.text: I remember way back when I was interning at Middle Temple and I had my first visit to this Wagamama.  I thought to myself, 'Why would anyone eat at a ramen restaurant?'  Since then, I've become quite a fan.  The food here is nice, simple, and tasty.  We're fans of the ramens and chicken katsu curry as well as the juices.  The kids enjoy the chicken ramen.  Whenever I'm in London I make a stop here :)  The view isn't so bad either!

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Katsu Curry
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Ramen
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom

yIHTUlWnhMV69ipBRU870Q.text: On a cold, windy afternoon, I craved a hot soup to warm me up and I spied Wagamama's just a short walk away.Upon entering, there were plenty of seats to choose from, so I was seated right away. I ordered a spicy noodle soup with chicken and was sorely disappointed.  The broth was not spicy at all, and in fact, was not even hot in regards to temperature!  The flavor was bland and no one came by to bring condiments (i.e. soy sauce) or a refill on my water.  I ended up just eating the chicken and leaving behind the noodles and broth.Wagamama's isn't exactly cheap, so I won't even blame the food on the price.  This was just plain bad.

VLD1Pkez43n3Byv9waN6Hw.text: I have been there with my boyfriend and a couple of friends on a saturday night after the imax.  Terrible food, with no taste or flavour and to be honest too pricy for what they offered in terms of menu.I had a gyoza with prawns and vegetables that were ok but the Cha han (rice, vegetables and prawns) was without any flavour at all! and the chicken had also a strange taste. The waiter also laugh at us when he brought us the gyoza and we asked plates as this dish was to share with other people. Not a nice service. At the end we won't go there again and I don't understand why this place is still full of people!not recommended.

KYsu6-1YifSTkTWNmFfjCg.text: My husband had never been to a Wagamamas restaurant before but chose it because it was within walking distance from the Menier Chocolate Factory where we'd seen a matinee performance.  He was also unaware that Wagamamas is the restaurant of choice for my daughter who was delighted to find out that was where we were going!There was a queue of people waiting to be seated but the staff were very quick to find us a table when they discovered that my husband was disabled and couldn't stand for too long.  It was quite busy and, having sat down, the waiter didn't realise that we hadn't been given menus and it was some time before we could attract his attention.In spite of the previous comment, the food was fairly quick to arrive at the table.  My husband and daughter had both ordered the saien soba (fried tofu, vegetables + noodles in soup)  and their bowls were massive!  I'd ordered yasai wagamama pad-thai which is egg-fried rice noodles in a tamarind sauce with fried tofu, egg, beansprouts, leeks, chinese chives, spring onions, garlic, ginger, mint and chillies. garnished with coriander cress, fried shallots, peanuts and lime.  It didn't look very much on the plate but was very filling.We'd just started eating when the manager brought over a bowl of edamame for us that he advised the chef had prepared one too many and thought we might like them.  Little did he know that edamame is a particular favourite of ours and something we normally order at Giraffe!  They were just salted and lacked that extra kick that the Giraffe ones have but we added some soy and chilli sauces - delicious!Hadn't intended having dessert but I couldn't resist the date and orange pancakes and my husband had the sweet ginger and apple gyoza - deep-fried apple + ginger dumplings.It was a lovely meal, my husband even came away saying we must definitely go back to a Wagamamas soon and pleased when we told him there's one in our local shoping centre!  No, we didn't get charged for the edamame (you never know) and even though we had desserts it wasn't an expensive evening.  Green tea is provided on the house and you just keep asking for top ups so there's no need to spend a fortune having a hot drink or one of their range of juices.The one downside was the echo effect because the walls were tiled. It was rather noisy at the start of the evening.Although they were busy and we had felt a bit ignored to start with, the service was very good such that my husband, one who doesn't normally tip, made a point of including a tip when he paid!

Ddw-oN2gQ04wx5dIX-u4oA.text: I've been to a few Wagamamas in my day, so I knew more or less what to expect when it came to food.  That boils down to affordable, passable Asian fare catered to a non-Asian palate.  I ordered the chicken kare lomen, a bowl of ramen noodles in a lemongrass curry broth.  It was good for a few bites, when the broth was still novel, but after that it got way too sweet.  The broth was also much less a broth than a sludge, and it wasn't the sort of thing you could slurp on its own.  The noodles were mediocre, like cheap spaghetti, without a bit of chew.  I tried some chili men which was a better dish, pretty fair with a little kick and noodles that were a little less cooked.  The yakisoba was thinly flavored, unlike any yakisoba I've ever seen.  I didn't touch Matt B.'s tiny portion of teriyaki beef, but he reported that while the sauce was good, the meat was awful.But, like I said, the food was more or less what I expected.  The food came quickly, too, and wine was cheap.  What got me about this Wagamama was a strange encounter our group of five had with management.We were a party of five, but four of us got seated first as the fifth was running behind.  When we tried to order her food, we were told that five people could not sit at our table, as it was designed for four.  There was plenty of room for a fifth person, but our waiter told us that there were concerns of too much food on the table, as a hot plate might fall in one of our laps.  He told us he would bring by a manager and, apparently, did not put in our last order.  Much, much later, after our hungry fifth arrived, the manager finally came by after the rest of us had already finished our food.  We tried to order food for one now that the table was cleared, but we were refused.  I then tried to order food for myself, and I was refused, with the observation that "that would be like ordering alcohol for an under-aged person."  Except, of course, that EATING is legal.Anyway, the staff was rude and unaccommodating and I don't think that our group of five reasonable people were being unreasonable.  I wouldn't go back to this Wagamama with its absurd policies and stubborn staff.  I can get chain noodles without the attitude elsewhere.

IV_Y7yGgYdv_tinInoGNmg.text: I used to love Wagamama. But apparently they've done some changes in the menu. A bit disappointed. Tried the prawn dumplings. Ah....not my thing! I noticed other interesting things though which I will definitely come back to try - teriyaki sticky rice with vegs and meat. Looked lovely.

BU-NjeQilQ_TFxtpVQVu1Q.text: Arrived at 22:40 and even though they closed at 11pm THEY LET ME IN! Is this life? I think so! :-))) I personally think they are winning from the outset. I ordered a new starter, something with chicken and mint on a skewer (Sorry I know that probably wasn't helpful) and was told that as it was new and some people hadn't been keen on it so I could have it on the house to see how I felt about it! FREE FOOD??!?!? I mean... come on now!? It WAS rank to be fair but hey, waste not want not right?I ordered the Chicken Katsu Curry (I usually go for the veg option but Carpe Diem and all that) which took longer than average to arrive. Ok, It was edible but in all honesty completely overcooked. I was offered a brand new one but I was so hungry my stomach had more rumble than a tumble dryer so I declined.Staff were all SUPER polite! You know that leaving the restaurant thinking "ahhhh she was REALLLLLLLY nice" kind of polite. Manager was BRILLIANT too.. the way she says "I don't like it" completely made my day. I don't suggest you ask her to say it but it was definitely a highlight, LOVELY woman.All in all a top class experience with mediocre food but these places are always touch and go depending on the chef.

Der2JFLbNRrRACbEkiw36g.text: Pretty tasteless across the whole menu to be honest. Service good but thats to be expected with a chain.If you actually like Asian food I'd avoid.Bloody pricey for what you get as well.

L7cthQge5tLbCJYT-9glWw.text: Not a fan of this place.  My friends came here for lunch.  I think this place being by the bank makes it somewhat unwelcoming.  The service was mediocre.  Considering they are a fast food chain, my friend had to wait a long time to get his food.The food was meh. I had garlic salt edamame and miso soup.  It was so-so.  My friend had some pan-fried noodle, and it was alright.  Another friend got udon (that's the one that took a lot time), and again, only alright.

oPRk_g5_bn6T2Fnaahywfw.text: It's almost like they are the same. Standard menu and tables. Setting is nice. Under the railway arches. Always a good value place to eat.

eueJ-DAvE2nxeSnJ_0wg8Q.text: Mmm... delicious, delicious Asian fusion. Being from Vancouver, this type of food is like comfort food for me. How could anyone NOT like delicious noodles and veggies?I was visiting a couple of friends in London and they took me here on one of my first nights in town. I found the architecture in this particular location to be stunning, as it was such a nice mixture of old and new. The food was also very tasty, and not badly priced considering it's London after all. It's a worthwhile stop if you're in the area!

o1suvEVfV5NOh0euxTOPEw.text: Why do I love this place so much?  Oh right.  Because the food in London is definitely known for being pretty bad and Wagamama is the only decent place I remember eating at.  This was my second Wagamama in two days of being in London and I was just happy to find something to eat.  I had the miso ramen, which tasted just fine.  Exactly what I wanted on a cold day in November.  It's great staring out the window looking at everyone walking by.  Perfect stop along the Thames.

73tcIBvnZTh8dTA8KKFYMQ.text: Slightly inauspicious street name aside, Wagamama's on Clink Street near London Bridge tube station is a beautifully located branch of this Asian chain housed beneath the railway arches just next to Nando's. If I'm honest, the last time I visited Wagamama's I was unceremoniously drunk and in need of some carbs. Pronto. The service was charming and fast and the food great. Just what you need when inebriated.A friend and I ordered the yummy Gyoza dumplings to start which pack a punch and are great to share with friends; and then the Ginger Chicken Udon which arrived in about five minutes flat, was ridiculously tasty and came in super generous portions. All in all a fabulous place for a quick, healthy meal which will set you back about a tenner a head in a picturesque location just near the South Bank.

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Photograph courtesy of http://www.wagamama.com/
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Photograph courtesy of http://www.wagamama.com/
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Photograph courtesy of http://www.wagamama.com/

uAxk77lyNAcHmb3jeXZyIA.text: If you are expecting amazing Asian food, don't bother coming here.  It is decent, but nothing special.  Do come here if you are an exhausted tourist and want to sit down and have a spectacular view of Tower Bridge.  It is not as crazy as it may seem based on the fact that it's right next to the Tower of London.  A great resting spot for me one day when I was totally exhausted.  The service is so-so, but the nice view makes up for it!

6XN-lItP_cg1AK-EQGjDXQ.text: I will give this a just ok as nothing special.  Not all wagamama are the same as some have better chefs and others are just cooks. This one have a good waiting staff but food served was just ok. I had to return a tasteless dish and they act upon it very professionally and gave me something else.  It's a handy stop if you are tired and want a quick bite. My favourite wagamama is at Kings way Holborn and Wigmore street as better food as I suspect they better chefs or better paid chef.

GOJpxVF9mHkFHPHPeTLrNg.text: I had wanted to visit Wagamama's for ages having heard such great things about their Asian approach to fast food. I'd even looked at the menu a couple of times online to figure out what I would order if the opportunity presented itself. Unfortunately, when I finally sat down at a table in the Clink Street branch the waitress instructed me that they had sold out of all the items I wanted. I was pretty gutted that they didn't have any dumplings left or any noodle dishes with prawns. It was only 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon so I wondered how much more they would run out of by the end of the day.The food we did order was very nice although I made the mistake of ordering a salad and had a bit of carb envy over my friends' noodles. She found her dish a bit too spicy but I think she brought that on herself by ordering the Chilli Beef Ramen. Everything arrived very quickly and we enjoyed a couple of Wagamama's fresh juices.Although I'd go back to Wagamama's in the future, it wouldn't be my first choice for Thai food or even my third or forth. It was great that our food arrived so fast but, as soon as we had finished our plates were lifted so quickly it was clear that the waitress wanted us out of there. Obviously this is a fast food restaurant and so these things have to be expected but I'm more of a sit back and relax kind of girl. Wagamama's is good but maybe we're just not suited to each other.

12pAnOFTKYzAW71uLPqICQ.text: If you're looking for authentic Asian cuisine, walk on. This chain is all about putting the spin on traditional food using local produce and product. Well presented, tasty, not too dear. And if you're in the 'hood, it sure is close.

7vzFBGu6cXcXkNA2fJhH8Q.text: When a menu is standard across so many restaurants it seems slightly weird to review a particular branch of a chain, but over the last couple of months I've eaten Wagamama's brilliant nosh in such a variety of places I thought it worth assessing my experiences. This riverside branch is my favourite because of the location - I like knowing I'm near water even if I can't see it from my table. I've eaten here three times in recent months to refuel partway through vocal recording sessions in Borough and came once at peak lunchtime and twice around 3pm, and while the food was superb every time the staff were patchy. On the last occasion my colleague and I arrived just after the lunch rush. The place was nearly empty of customers and staff it seemed, as we hung around by the front door sniffing the fragrant noodle-y air wistfully. Remember that when the tummy is empty the urgency of time presses more firmly on a person, so forgive us for losing patience, foraging for menus and seating ourselves, accompanied by a little huff-and-puff. Still no-one came to welcome us - mighty strange, we thought. But as I trotted off to use the loo the mystery was revealed when I passed a bustling table at the back of the restaurant marked Staff Dining. That's where everyone was! Warning - this Wagamama's can be lethal. It's way too tempting to curtail any semblance of a productive work day by nipping in to Vinopolis (next door) when you've finished your healthy lunch. Leave via the river!

WEsVKyOoXLRFVSGM0QCMQQ.text: I shall forever have a soft spot for the Clink Street Branch of Wagamama. The staff there are so friendly and so nice. If you end up with Kat, it will be entertainment all the way. As for the others, they are all so lovely. The service has always been consistently good, food is cheap, tasty and interesting. I'm sure everyone has something they like at Wagamama. I personally love the chilli beef ramen, as well as the chicken katsu curry. But one thing I must have whenever I go there is the edamame! Especially if you get to flick them at your friends and loved ones.

n3YdR51g3qOFDSH133AWeg.text: This is a very busy Wagamama. So much so it does feel very much like a canteen. Food was up to w.mama's usual standards, however service was very brief, with there being far fewer staff than i would expect of a restaurant that size. Usual wagamama style, but with railway arch type feel. It did exactly as planned - decent food of known standard, quickly. But if i was looking for somewhere special to go, then i would choose another venue.

G1kJkv7VMyPUlIXBt7Zj2g.text: Was craving some ramen and looking for something quick, and this was the spot! So I only recently found out this was also in NYC, but this ramen place is based out of London! The ramen is very healthy and clean, and possibly the healthiest ramen I've had. It's a bit bland, but I still enjoyed it! Would come back again, and also interested in maybe trying their locations in NYC to see how it compares.

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom

1GbqAaWU9qUZUXUtRUr5cw.text: Food was good. Service was awful. At first, we were seated without being given any menus. Then, we never saw our server again after he brought us our food. Lastly, I had to ask not once, not twice, but THREE times to have my water refilled. I was only given another glass of water after speaking to (who I assumed was the manager) and she said "the bar is really busy". We had to ask for our check and when the time came to pay, not a single word was exchanged. I would recommend Wagamama to others, just definitely not this location.

WO9su6rNQ2ZWD9ru2j7meg.text: I came here with my boyfriend because we love asian food but to our surprise, it wasn't yummy ! I guess because it's a fast food chain restaurant in London but my Donburi rice looked to be undercooked or old. It was very strange and made the whole dish kind of gross. I'm disappointed but the kimchi side was delicious and the drink was tasty. We will probably not come back :/

r-BCqzZ406dlJnI1mF5T0w.text: The Vegan Katsu!!  First time in London I was a bit iffy about what food they'd have and what I'd be able to stomach.  Glad my friend mentioned this place.  As I mentioned the Vegan Katsu, I assumed it was tofu but the meat substitute they use had a different texture.  It's a mix of Asian and Indian fusion.  What with the Curry sauce.  I went three days back to back

DEp4hP1tO0NbcXEhjIBOCg.text: I had previously had wagamama in New York. My brother and I were both ecstatic to come across it during our stay in London. We knew going in that the meals come out at separate times but after receiving my meal it took my brother over an hour to get his. Luckily our server was very courteous and brought us a round of drinks on the house and dessert was on the house. His customer service went above and beyond which saved our second experience at wagamama. The food was delicious. We ordered to start pork gyoza, I recommend getting them grilled. My main meal was the short rib ramen. The rib was so tender and the meat fell right off the short bone... mouth watering haha. Overall, I'd recommend the ramen it will come out the quickest.

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom

cy5qigfS1V78qQ-8BMYS2w.text: The atmosphere is nice, clean, very well presented.  Unfortunately presentation is not everything, the chili ramen with chicken looked good, the chicken was very dry and the broth was lacking any resemblance of flavor.  Tried to improve it with Shichimi and soy, but couldn't fix it.  On a better note the staff was pleasant and my pork belly buns were decent.  I enjoyed the fruit, went with the super green, I would order it again.  Rating is low due to how pathetic the ramen was.

394Hnh418LIRJJjZNoxo2A.text: Horrible service. Asked for cold water and said they don't have it while everyone around me are drinking it. Asked for green tea which is free on the menu but was told I hav to pay 3 pounds. This place sucks. Avoid this place if you are tourist.

BuEW136I2cAcEVf2wkIfRA.text: Hard to get my kids excited about most restaurant fare on a long European vacation, but this was a hit. Beef steamed bun was great. Donburi good, ramen too.

nrJZcV7q11xIpRk1GOdFqQ.text: Great vegan options! The ramen was some of the best ever and the bao buns were so flavorful and delicious. Highly recommended

zjy_tmXQKL1HuFcKTYL-kw.text: Daughter forced us into wagamama, i was going to nandos next door, wow forvet nandos this was possibly one of the best meals i have had, full of flavour and so fulfilling and a lovely runny egg cant beat it.

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom

euNiq-uTYC3pb590KmMeeg.text: On our way to Shakespeare's Globe Theatre in Southwark, we chanced upon Wagamama. My friend had suggested this place to us, but we did not know if we were going to have the time to seek it out. So, we decided that this will be our post-theatre dining venue that evening since it is on the way back to the London Bridge tube station from The Globe Theatre. We started with the Chili Garlic Salt Edamame and the Pulled Pork Gyoza. The edamame was really good. The chili and salt gave it an extra kick of flavor. My husband and I both did not like the Pulled Pork Gyoza however. Too sweet! Both the filling and the sauce were sweet, so that taste overpowered everything else. You need to balance out that sweetness with some extra acidity. Maybe more vinegar in the sauce?It was disappointing not to see tonkotsu listed on the ramen part of the menu, but I thought I'd try the ramen anyway. They only serve miso based soups. I settled for the Wagamama ramen which seemed to have everything under the sun in it. It had chicken, pork, clams, mussels, shrimp and a tea stained egg. The egg yolk was overdone and the broth was just okay. The chicken was tasteless, and the other stuff in it, again, just okay.  I would not recommend this dish. Try maybe one of the curries or the Yaki Udon. My husband had the Yaki Udon dish and it was good. It had a nice flavor and the thick noodles made the dish filling enough. However, it's not a very generous amount, so if you are hungry, don't share it with others. Service was good and our food came out in a timely manner. Note that the service charge is not included in the check, so you will have to add a 12% tip.

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom

kMeFqOxnGNnFuJDMqc0U5Q.text: Would give it 3.5 stars but am rounding up. We had pad thai, and it was decent. We asked that ours be cooked without nuts, and they took great care to do so which I appreciated. Ambience was also decent. High ceiling and relatively spacious. Service was also prompt and good in general. As said, when we asked for our dishes without nuts, one of the managers personally came to check on other allergies and informed us that there are nuts in the kitchen in general so would we be okay with that. Overall, a solid experience, though I'd like to try out some other dishes to get a true sense.

9p3vvAfyqyd_JitKFFTPug.text: The food was ok, not great, rather bland, but it came quite quickly. The atmosphere was the worst part. It was incredibly loud and chaotic. It felt rushed. Between people talking and the music trying to drown them out I never ended up with what I had ordered. First they brought the entirely wrong order to us. Then everyone else's food arrived, and my pork gyoza (steamed) somehow it ended up being steamed pork buns. When they realized they had gotten it wrong they attempted to fix it, and that somehow turned into duck gyoza (fried). I finally just gave up. They gave us the pork buns free, but none of us wanted them so they just sat there. The most frustrating thing was someone else in our party also ordered pork gyoza and they arrived with no issue. There are better places to eat than here, and I would recommend passing this place by; at least this particular location. Also the sauce that came with the gyoza was beyond sickly sweet.

muTQZBarsmdH3-RLbRdoCg.text: I was in the area for work, and to be honest, a Wagamama pretty much always sounds good. This one isn't too huge and is in a nice place, near Borough Market and Bankside. Service was fine, if a bit slow. Food was the same as ever. The sun coming in through the huge windows was a bit of an issue. It wasn't a hot day but it was a bit greenhouse-like inside.So yep, 3 stars, a-okay. I wouldn't come here especially, and it was only because I was in that dead zone time of 3.30pm, having not had lunch, too hungry to wait till dinner, that made this an ideal choice for the area. When you're steps away from Borough Market, if the traders are there, you should be there, too. If you find yourself caught out, this Wagamama will be just fine.

_M0dVX0eYyEuJf--C1o3IA.text: This is my favourite Wagamama! Why? Because of the tempura mushrooms. The end.It's like all the others, things come out as they are cooked and they have great veggie options. But this one still have these mushrooms on the menu and they are not to be missed!

9LGqSY7fM_4Fs1jhRekr3Q.text: Wagamama (pretty much all locations) is my favorite go-to place in London and the one place I seriously crave when I'm away. There is no other way to say it... the food is delicious, and warms you from the inside out on gray, rainy London days. The portions are huge and a late lunch will easily keep you satisfied until late evening. They offer a few Asian branded beers to purchase by the bottle, FREE hot green tea, and fresh pressed juices, as well as the standard soft drinks. In general, the service is pretty great, but expect to get your food as it's ready - not everyone at the table receives their food at the same time. Many restaurants in London are kid-friendly, but Wagamama takes it a step further with an affordable kids' menu of with kid-friendly versions and portions of food from the regular menu, high chairs, and training chopsticks for the little ones.

ZYfVE6orueYFsjiIVIozGQ.text: Great place! My family and I were greeted immediately with friendly and funny staff! The French guy was pretty funny. Excellent service! They tolerated our obsession with ice in our drinks. The food was fantastic ! Very modern and simple . Great place ! Totally coming back!

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. The pot stickers are delicious ! I don't know what this sauce but it's sweet and tasty!

XZndxb3uSKWbI515cpy9dw.text: Fantastic service, excellent food at a reasonable price, the Korean BBQ steam buns are a must do!

QSy5t23RnCmPKX8Hffk0Wg.text: With London in the grips of a heatwave there are only two things that you want; a cold beer and some aircon.  We dipped into Wagamama thinking we'd find both and were sadly mistaken.The front of the restaurant is all windows which makes for a miserable situation inside.  It felt like a sauna and a tanning booth all at once.  There were a couple of spots in the shade, but they were minimal compared to the overall size of the place.When we were seated we specifically asked for shade.  Seems the waitress's idea of shade and ours was different.  For her, my back being baked in the sun while my wife enjoyed the shade was good enough.  Of course, we had to move tables.  The second sin was serving us room temperature beer. The final straw (mixing metaphors here) was having the ONLY section completely in the shade closed off to paying customers.  It seems the employees NEEDED this area to sit around, shoot the shit, and generally ignore their melting customers.  It's sad when the customers have to show the employees how to operate the blinds in the front of the restaurant.The food may have been amazing, but it's hard to appreciate when you're suffering the effects of heat stroke.  An apathetic staff didn't help the ambiance either.  As much as I love this chain I won't be returning to this location.

hiHp2rft--Ap6efrxUdrmA.text: When you go to Wagamama you expect something as it is a popular chain on the high street but to be honest with you, I think it is over rated.  To say it is Japanese fusion is not fare on the great Japanese food we have in London. I ordered a agadashi tofu which was not authentic and the stock doesn't taste of anything.  Even in cheap Japanese restaurants they do a much better job of this dish.  This was followed by Pad Thai which again lacked flavour and was not authentic.  For the cost of these noodles you expect something but get nothing in return.  The service was polite but nothing special.I don't recommend Wagamama in Clink Street and it is also overpriced.
